page.title: 07Arable Farming -Farlesthorpe
page.content: The farmer has run a 164 acre farm in Farlesthorpe for 18 years. It was owned at first by the John Spendluffe school and it was then given to the Grammar school in Alford in the 17th century. The farm is predominantly arable, growing wheat (100 acres), potatoes, barley, and oil seed rape (all 20 acres). The remaining 4 acres is taken up by roads, hedges and buildings. The land is fertile but fertiliser still has to be purchased in order to improve the land. The farm is very mechanised; the farmer owns all his own equipment - even combine harvesters. Even so, the farm still has to employ 4 or 5 men or schoolboys in the summer months to act as casual labourers.
